subject: XPhy_Education
text: The National Education Policy 2020 envisages a system of education in the country that is rooted in Indian ethos and its civilisational accomplishments in all domains of human endeavours and knowledge, while at the same time preparing the students to constructively engage with the prospects and challenges of the 21st century. The basis for this aspirational vision has been well laid out by the National Curriculum Framework for School Education (NCF- SE) 2023 across curricular areas at all stages. Having nurtured the students’ inherent abilities and touching upon all the five planes of human existence, the pafichakoshas, in the Foundational and the Preparatory Stages have paved the way for the progression of their learning further at the Middle Stage. Thus, the Middle Stage acts asa bridge between the Preparatory and the Secondary Stages, spanning three years from Grade 6 to Grade 8. The NCF-SE 2023, at the Middle Stage, aims to equip students with the skills that are needed to grow, as they advance in their lives. It endeavours to enhance their analytical, descriptive, and narrative capabilities and to prepare them for the challenges and opportunities that await them. A diverse curriculum, covering nine subjects ranging from three languages—including at least two languages native to India—to Science, Mathematics, Social Sciences, Art Education, Physical Education and Well-being, and Vocational Education promotes their holistic development. Such a transformative learning culture requires certain essential conditions. One of them is to have appropriate textbooks in different curricular areas as these textbooks will play a central role in mediating between content and pedagogy—a role that will strike a

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Prelims.indd 3 19-Jul-24 5:22:58 PM

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Prelims.indd 4

subject: XPhy_Education
text: iv

subject: XPhy_Education
text: judicious balance between direct instruction and opportunities for exploration and inquiry. Among the other conditions, classroom arrangement and teacher preparation are crucial to establishing conceptual connections both within and across curricular areas. The National Council of Educational Research and Training, on its part, is committed to providing students with such high-quality textbooks. Various Curricular Area Groups, which have been constituted for this purpose, comprising notable subject experts, pedagogues, and practicing teachers as their members, have made all possible efforts to develop such textbooks.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Adhering to the recommendations of the National Curriculum Framework for School Education, a new subject area called ‘Physical Education and Well-being’ has been introduced at the Middle Stage. This subject aims to promote love for physical activity and sports; develop capacities for skillful engagement in sports; and develop resilience, empathy, and cooperation. India has a wonderful tradition of Yoga which is a wholesome experience for maintaining mind and body wellbeing. The subject of Physical Education and Well-being includes various aspects of Yoga starting from Yama, Niyama, Asana, Pranayama and Dhyana in a progressive way from Class 3 till the Secondary Stage. This lays the foundation for holistic health and well-being.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: The book for Physical Education and Well-being, titled Khel Yatra for Grade 6, is meticulously designed to develop motor skills and engage children in the team sports of Kho-kho and Hand ball. Age-specific aspects of Yoga are designed to lay the foundation for healthy living. The textbook aligns with the competencies included in the NCF-SE 2023 for this stage.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Khel Yatra emphasises the importance of physical activity and the values and dispositions essential for life. It incorporates cross-cutting themes, such as inclusion, gender equality, and cultural rootedness.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Prelims.indd 5

subject: XPhy_Education
text: The content and activities are designed to encourage peer group learning, and enrich the educational experience for both students and teachers. While this textbook is valuable, children should also explore interesting local games and play with friends. This book is not only useful for school learning, but also a valuable resource for parents and community.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: However, in addition to this textbook, students at this stage should also be encouraged to explore various other learning resources. Schoollibraries play a crucial role in making such resources available. Besides, the role of parents and teachers will also be invaluable in guiding and encouraging students to do so. With this, I express my gratitude to all those who have been involved in the development of this textbook and hope that it will meet the expectations of all stakeholders. At the same time, I also invite suggestions and feedback from all its users for further improvement in the coming years.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: The National Curriculum Framework for School Education 2023 (NCF-SE 2023) recognises the criticality of the health and well- being of individuals as a key factor for success in all aspects of life. Considering the focus on holistic well-being, NCF-SE has mandated Physical Education and Well-being as a core curricular area for

subject: XPhy_Education
text: all stages of school education. To help the teachers and students achieve curricular goals of Physical Education and Well-being, for the first time a textbook has been designed for Grade 6. This book enables students to experience the joy of playing, explore diverse physical activities, practice fitness skills, learn basic sports skills, and immerse in the world of yoga. Sports and physical activities teach important motor skills, socio-emotional awareness and regulation, associated cognitive abilities, as well as the values of self-discipline, hard work, teamwork, and a gracious acceptance of one’s strengths and vulnerabilities.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: To achieve the goals of fitness, sports and holistic well-being, the Grade 6 textbook is designed to have five units.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 1. Understanding the importance of Physical education

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 2. Motor fitness

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 3. Introduction to Kho-Kho

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 4. Introduction to Handball

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 5. Yoga

subject: XPhy_Education
text: In Unit 1, students explore the connection between physical education

subject: XPhy_Education
text: (PE) and well-being, emphasizing its impact on personal and social behaviour. Through playing games and engaging in discussions,

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Prelims.indd 8

subject: XPhy_Education
text: viii

subject: XPhy_Education
text: students will understand the importance of living a healthy lifestyle and how physical activity adds to their overall enjoyment and success. Students will also learn about the safety measures to minimize the risk of injuries and create a healthy environment for the players.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: In Unit 2, students learn different fitness components like endurance, strength, flexibility, and balance. The main aim is to understand how each of these components contributes to overall health.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: In the Units 3 and 4 focus is on learning new games. Kho Kho is introduced in Unit 3 and Handball in Unit 4. Through interactive sessions and group exercises, students will discover the excitement of sport and health advantages of physical activity. The emphasis will be on inclusivity, team cohesion, and enjoyment of movement.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: In the last unit, students immerse in the holistic nature of yoga. They learn about Yama (social discipline) and Niyama (Personal discipline) to inculcate healthy habits for positive behavior. Systematic practice of various yogasanas starting with Sukshma Vyayama (loosening exercises), preparatory breathing practices and step-by-step performance of each asana helps our body to be flexible, strong, balanced and disease free. Various techniques of Pranayama strengthen the lungs, improves functioning of major systems of our body, calm down the mind, improve concentration and help in achieving overall harmony and well-being. To explore the world within us and experience deep sense of peace, tranquility and bliss, students learn different techniques of Dharana (single pointed concentration) and Dhyana (meditation). Learning various yogic practices lays foundation for long and healthy life.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: In this book, apart from learning the games and physical activities, students will learn to follow rules, understand the importance of safe practices and fair play, work harmoniously in groups, treat each other with courtesy and respect, as well as, help each other, and experience the joy of playing together. Inculcation of these values and dispositions will partly happen while children are engaged in

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Prelims.indd 9

subject: XPhy_Education
text: the physical activities or games and partly, they will be reinforced during circle time after the game. Sufficient time must be given for circle time during the Physical Education and Well-being periods.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Structure and Flow of Classes

subject: XPhy_Education
text: NCF-SE 2023 has recommended 120 periods for physical education and well-being in Grade 6. Suggestive timetable assumes at least 5 periods of 40 minute each, per week. NCF-SE recommends allocating block period (2 periods together) for physical education and well- being. If it is not possible to allocate two block periods and one single period every week, it is necessary to design single periods with different focus to ensure sufficient time for activities, game and circle time.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Suggestions are given below for two different scenarios of timetable.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: e Scenario 1 — Five single periods per week.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: ¢ Scenario 2 - Two block periods for Units 1 to 4 and single period for yoga.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Scenario 1: Three different types of sessions have been visualised to effectively use the limited time in each period and achieve the learning outcomes.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: ¢ Type 1: Maximizes game practice.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: ° Type 2: Maximizes circle time after play to provide sufficient time for discussing cognitive and socio-emotional aspects.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: ¢ Type 3: Maximizes gamified drills to focus on one specific skill.

text: Instruction r chers

subject: XPhy_Education
text: For joyful experience, safety of children and effective development

subject: XPhy_Education
text: of competencies, teachers may follow the instructions given below:

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Ensure adequate play area and there are no obstructions in the play area.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: For group activities, mark the area into smaller blocks to prevent students from running into each other.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: While dividing the teams make sure that the teams are fair and balanced in terms of bodyweight, height and skills required for the activity.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Ensure that a first aid kit is available and accessible.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Ensure that students are treated with respect and they feel emotionally and socially safe.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Provide regular encouragement and support to all the students. Ensure students have access to fair redressal of grievances during the Physical Education period.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Encourage students to be aware of their surroundings while playing.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Instruct the students not to aim at the opponent, unless told otherwise, and discuss why this is important.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Encourage the students to be careful while pushing or pulling the opponent in the activity.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Ensure that students do proper warm-up and cool-down. Encourage them to create their own routines.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Provide opportunities to students for interactions before, during and after the class.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Prelims.indd 12

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Introduced sports skills gradually. Complexity can be increased by playing mini versions of the sport gradually building individual capacities such as observation, reflection, emotional regulation, expanding spatial awareness and peripheral vision, and making quick judgements based on gameplay.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Discuss social capacities such as effective communication, collective decision making, and working together towards a common goal, during circle time and at relevant moments in the sport.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Encourage students to take more responsibility for building a

subject: XPhy_Education
text: culture of inclusive sports at school. Help them to take an active

subject: XPhy_Education
text: role in ensuring all students feel safe, motivated, and encouraged to play.

text: Importance of Physical Education and Well-being 13

subject: XPhy_Education
text: In this unit, we will learn about the importance of fitness. We will also understand that being fit can help us to be healthy and strong. Here are a few things we can do to be fit:

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 1. Endurance: We will do fun activities that will help us to play longer without getting tired.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 2. Building strength: We will get stronger with regular exercise. It will build our muscles and bones.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 3. Becoming flexible: When we stretch and move in guided ways, our bodies will become flexible.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 4. Learning balance: When we practice being steady while playing and exercising, we also learn to balance our body.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Let’s get moving and explore fitness with fun!

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Physical Education Unit 2.indd 14 20-Jul-24 2:56:53 PM

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Introductionito Moto Fitness

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Motor Fitness refers to the ability of our body’s muscles

subject: XPhy_Education
text: and nerves to work together effectively and efficiently. It involves skills like coordination, balance, agility, and reaction time. Good motor fitness helps us to perform daily tasks

subject: XPhy_Education
text: and activities easily and with control. But before we do any activity, we need to understand the concepts and techniques of warm-up, cool-down and stretching. Let us start our journey of fitness with the right first step!

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Why is warm-up important?

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Warming up prepares the body for an activity, by raising the body temperature and heart

subject: XPhy_Education
text: rate which improves physical efficiency and performance. Warming up, stretching muscles and moving joints prior to an activity minimises the risk of injury.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: ee

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Motor Fitness 15

subject: XPhy_Education
text: How to warm-up?

subject: XPhy_Education
text: For approximately 5-10 minutes engage

subject: XPhy_Education
text: in any progressively light to intense grade exercise related to the sporting activity can be performed. For example, football kick, rugby ball passing, lifting light weights, shadow boxing, etc., followed by general exercises such as jogging, shuttle runs, high knee sprints can be perfomed. Once you start feeling energised, stretching exercises must be performed prior to commencing the sport or activity.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Why Should we stretch? --:--:: cee nes

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Stretching exercises are recommended before and after participating in any sport as they prepare the body for the forthcoming physical activity by enabling joints to move through their full range of motion. Pre-stretching reduces the risk of injury and post-stretching helps in recovery.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: HOW C0 SCHOCCH? 0. eee bebe bebe ee eee eee a

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Keep your body relaxed. During stretching, concentrate on taking slow and deep breaths. Flexibility improves when the mind and muscles are relaxed. Everyone’s ability to move and flexibility varies as they depend on physical characteristics, fitness levels and age. Always remember to stretch within your limitations and do not try to compete.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Some Stretching Exercises Overhead Arm Stretch

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Stand straight with a gap between your feet. Now raise both arms simultaneously upwards and then lock fingers of both hands. Push your arms upwards with palms facing the sky, as shown in the picture.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Variation: Lean forward and backward whilst arms outstretched.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Rear Shoulder Stretch

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Stand straight with your feet joined together or closer to each other. Move your arms towards your back and try to join them backwards. Now lock your fingers of both the hands and push your arms backwards as far as possible.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Variation: Lean forward whilst pushing hands backwards to increase intensity.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Overhead Triceps Stretch

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Stand straight with gap between your feet. Raise your arms upward. Bend one of your arms from elbow behind the neck. Hold it from elbow with the other hand and pull sidewards. Repeat the same with the other arm.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Variation: Bend your upper body in the direction of the pull.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Motor Fitness

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Chest Stretch

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Stand straight with a gap between your feet. Now raise both your arms like an open hug posture and then stretch both your arms as much as possible, so that you can feel the stretch of your chest. Swing them backwards as far as possible.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Variation: Bend your elbows to form almost 90-degree angle and do the same stretch.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Hip Circles

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Stand straight with a gap between your feet. Then put both hands on the sides of your waist. Now rotate hips forming large circles in both clockwise and anti-clockwise direction keeping the legs straight as shown in the picture.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Variation: Place your hands straight on your sides and bend sideways alternately letting your hands slide sliding hand towards your knee one after the other.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Torso Twist

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Stand straight with feet shoulder width apart. Raise both the arms parallel to the ground and rotate your upper body using your hands and shoulders while keeping your lower body still. Repeat it in the other direction.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Variation: Raise your arms above your head and do the same twist.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Khel Yatra

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Squat

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Stand straight with a gap between your feet. Now raise both the arms up and place them with crossed fingers at the back of your head. After that, slowly lower your body as if you are sitting on an invisible chair while keeping your head straight with the same position as above and keeping your back straight.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Variation: Change the position of your arms to increase or decrease the difficulty level.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Quadriceps Stretch

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Stand straight with gap between your feet. Now balance on one leg and move the other leg backwards. Hold the ankle of the leg bent backward and pull it towards your hip as close as possible. Repeat the same with the other leg.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Variation: Lean your body forward while doing the same stretch.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Floor Touch

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Stand straight and keep your feet apart. Raise both arms straight upwards, parallel to each other, adjacent to both ears, as if each earlobe is covered by both inner arms. Now, slowly lean forward in the same position and try touching the floor with both palms without bending your knees.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Variation: Stay in the stretch and move your palms on the floor forward and backward.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Motor Fitness

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Calf Stretch

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Stand straight in front of a wall at an arm length. Placing both hand on the wall. Now place one foot in front of the other and slightly bend the knee of that leg. You must ensure that the heel of your back leg is touching the floor. Feel upper calf stretch in the back leg.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Variation: Move your back leg further backwards to increase the stretch.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Crossed-leg Toe Touch

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Stand straight with both feet joined together. Now cross one of the legs without bending. The leg which is crossed should be slightly ahead of the other leg. Lower your upper body to touch the toe of the crossed leg with both the arms.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Variation: You may stand on heels with crossed leg while staying in the stretch.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Crouch-leg Stretch

subject: XPhy_Education
text: First, sit down while balancing the body weight on both your knees and on your feet. Now stretch out one leg such that it is completely straight and the toe is raised towards the top, as shown in the picture.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: The balance of the other foot should be on the toes entirely and you can touch the floor with both hands for balance.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Khel Yatra

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Groin Stretch

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Sit down on the floor, one leg crossing over the other. Now gently bring the soles of your feet together. Grab each foot with your hands and place your elbows against the inner thighs. Keep your back straight during this stretch.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Variation: Try the same stretch in supine lying position.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Hip Stretch

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Sit down and stretch both the legs straight with the feet joined together. Now bend one leg and cross it over the inner thigh of the other leg.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Variation: Try the same stretch in lying position alternately with single and both legs.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Hamstring Stretch

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Lay down on the floor in supine position. Then, lift one leg as shown in the figure. Now provide support to the inner thigh below the knee with both hands and try to pull the bended leg towards the chest.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Variation: Sit with your legs straight in front of you. Try to reach your toes without bending your knees.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Motor Fitness

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Abdomen Stretch

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Lay down on your stomach. Place your hands on the floor next to your ears. Now lift your upper body with the support of your arms and straighten the arms completely so that the shoulders are parallel to the earlobes.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Variation: Stay in the position and try to lift both legs together.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: After the physical activity gently stretch your body for 5-10 minutes. Perform the exercises as illustrated above focusing on relaxing the muscles from head to toe. Include deep breathing exercises for relaxation.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: In this unit, we will learn about an exciting Indian sport called Kho-Kho. This game is interesting and helps us to work together as a team.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Kho-Kho is a sport where two teams compete. One team tries to tag members of the opponent team while they avoid being tagged. The game involves quick movement, agility, speed, leg strength and teamwork, with players taking turns to defend and chase. Here’s what we will do:

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 1. Learn and Play: We will have fun sessions where we will learn how to play Kho-Kho through interactive games and group exercises.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 2. Develop Skills: We will do exciting lead up activities to develop kho-kho skills.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 3. Workasa Team: We will focus on working together and supporting each other during the game.

text: LEAD-UP ACTIVITY . Standing Kho-Kho: Form a circle. Form six groups and stand at the circle’s border. One of you will be the chaser, while the other will be the runner. ‘Chaser’ can enter the circle, but the runner cannot. When the runner wishes to pass, then only entry is allowed in the circle and then the runner can stand in front of the lane. The runner will join the lane in which the last person will become the runner. If the chaser catches the runner, the runner turns into the chaser and vice versa.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: In this unit, we will learn about the game ofhandball. This is a fast-paced invasive team sport played with a ball. Players pass, dribble and shoot the ball to score points. Defence involves intercepting passes and blocking the shots. Here’s what we will do:

text: 1. Learnand Play: We willlearn howto play Handball through interactive games and exercises.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 2. Better Coordination, Strength and Endurance: Handball will help us in improving our coordination, strength, and endurance.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 3. Team Spirit: We will focus on working together, involving everyone, and supporting each other during the game.

text: Let us get ready to play handball, work as a team

subject: XPhy_Education

text: It might be a half-court or a smaller area of the handball court to increase the difficulty level. The team with the ball begins the game and must aim to complete ten consecutive passes. text: eg Sadhu and Shaitan: It involves four children dribbling within a

subject: XPhy_Education
text: : marked area (sadhu) while two children (shaitan) will try to stop them. Four cones are set up in the four corners, roughly 4 metres away from one another. The players are numbered from 1 to 4. Players 1 and 3 will have one ball each and will start the game at the same time. On the sound of the whistle, Player 1 will dribble the ball twice and throw it towards the Player 2, and then run and take the place of Player 2. Similarly, Player 3 will dribble twice and throw the ball towards the Player 4. This will create a relay and two players will try to stop this relay by blocking the ball. Whoever succeeds in obstructing the ball will exchange the role with the player and relay continues.

text: Battle of Balloons: Set up two poles each of 2 metres height at a distance of 3 metres. Now, tie balloons at the top and bottom of both the poles. Name the four points of the pole as Right Top (RT), Right Bottom (RB), Left Top (LT), Left Bottom (LB). Line up students 6 metres away from the poles. On the sound of the whistle, each student will run towards the pole and take the position right in the centre of the poles. The teacher then calls RT, RB, LT and LB randomly and the player has to do quick movements to touch the balloons either with their hands or legs. Each player will get ten chances. After finishing the drill, the player will return to the starting line.

text: Physical Education Unit 5.indd 109

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Welcome to the world of Yoga for holistic health and well-being. In this unit, let us explore the ancient art and science of Yoga —

subject: XPhy_Education
text: a practice that originated in India and endured for thousands of years. Passed down through generations in India, it is now enjoyed by people all around the world.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Yoga is a journey of self-discovery to keep our body strong and mind calm. We will delve into the rich practices of Yoga, exploring its history, philosophy and practical applications. From the fundamental principles of healthy living to the intricacies of different yogic practices, each section offers valuable insights and practical activities or steps to enhance your understanding and practice of Yoga.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: It is a common misconception that Yoga is simply a form of physical exercise involving complex breathing techniques, twists, turns and stretches. In its true sense, Yoga is a profound science that can unfold the infinite potentials of the human mind and soul.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Whether you area beginner seeking to embark on your Yogic journey or a practitioner looking to deepen your knowledge, this unit serves as a comprehensive resource to support your exploration and growth in the realm of Yoga. Let us embark on this transformative journey, unlocking the secrets of Yoga and discovering the boundless capabilities that lie within each of us.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: This unit begins with an introduction to Yoga before delving into a deeper understanding of Yama (social discipline) and Niyama (personal discipline) and their applications in daily life, Sukshsma Vyayama (joint movements), Sithaltkarana vyayama (loosening exercises), Pranayama (breathing practices), Asanas (postures), Pratyahara (mastery over senses), relaxation, Dharana (concentration), Dhydna (meditation) and Krida Yoga (Yoga games).

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Yoga Session Structure

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Start each Yoga session with a prayer given below. It is about the sacred bond between a student and the teacher. Both pray together to illuminate their paths with divine protection and nourishment with wisdom. They wish for peace everywhere and for everyone.

subject: XPhy_Education

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Chapter 1

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Yoga for Daily Life

subject: XPhy_Education
text: As students, you have busy schedules filled with classes, activities, projects and homework. Yoga can help you manage these activities by keeping your mind clear and focused. It can also improve physical health, making it easier to participate in sports and other activities. By incorporating Yoga into your daily routine, you will find it easier to stay calm and energised throughout the day.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Yoga helps you to focus and be more aware of your thoughts and feelings. It helps you get stronger and more flexible. It can improve your concentration, so you might find it easier to pay attention in class or while doing homework. Yoga can help you relax by helping you let go of your worries, especially if you are feeling stressed about school or other things. Overall, doing Yoga can make you feel happier and more at ease. Even a few minutes of Yoga each day can make a big difference. It’s a great way to take care of your body and mind.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: History of Yoga

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Yoga's roots can be traced back to the Vedas, the oldest sacred texts of India. During this time, people practised Yoga to connect with nature and the divine. Each chapter of the Bhagavad Gita, part of the epic Mahabharata, is named after different types of Yoga, including Karma Yoga (Yoga of action), Bhakti Yoga (Yoga of devotion), Jnana Yoga (Yoga of wisdom) and Raja Yoga (Yoga of willpower).

subject: XPhy_Education
text: LOT nti

subject: XPhy_Education
text: _ Ag orgs nas Yoga 113

subject: XPhy_Education
text: More than 2,000 years ago, Maharsi Patanjali compiled the practices of Yoga in 196 Yoga Sutras. These sutras describe a step-by-step path to achieve the highest state of bliss (Samadhi) through systematic practices defined as the eight limbs or aspects, called Ashtanga Yoga. We will learn more about Ashtanga Yoga later in this chapter.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Yoga continued to evolve with new practices and ideas. Hatha Yoga, which deals with the practical aspects of Yoga, was developed around 1,500 years ago.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: In the 19th and 20th centuries, Yoga masters like Swami Vivekananda, Paramahamsa Yogananda, Sage Aurobindo and B.K.S. Iyengar brought Yoga to the rest of the world. Today, Yoga is practised globally; the International Day of Yoga is celebrated on 21*June in more than 190 countries.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: What is Yoga?

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Ancient Indians had discovered that practising Yoga, can lead one to good health and well-being. Yoga can be defined as the science of healthy and happy living. It helps us to be peaceful and efficient in our work, study and other activities and move towards the full realisation of our potential.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: The term Yoga is derived from the Sanskrit word “yuj” which means “to unite or integrate”. It signifies the union of the body, mind and inner self. Yoga is about bringing different parts of yourself to create balance, harmony and a sense of oneness — both within and with the world around you. It also helps make the mind still, quiet and free from all distractions.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Yoga involves systematic efforts, not haphazard actions. Efforts become fruitful only through disciplined actions.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Let’s explore the eight aspects of Ashtanga Yoga, which consists of the systematic processes formulated by Maharsi Patanjali.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: These eight aspects are explained below:

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 1. Yama (Social Discipline)

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 8. Samadhi 2. Niyama (Blissful Experience) | — _\ (Personal Discipline) 7. Dhyana 3. Asana (Contemplation) (Posture) 6. Dharana 4, Pranayama (Concentration) (Mastery over Breath)

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 5. Pratyahara (Mastery over Senses)

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 1. Yama (Social Discipline and Ethics): These are guidelines about how to behave towards others, such as being kind and honest.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 2. Niyama (Personal Discipline): These are guidelines about how to take care of yourself, like keeping clean and being content.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 3. Asana (Posture): Performing Yoga postures daily to make our body strong and flexible.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 4. Pranayama (Mastery over Breath or Breath control): This is about controlling the breath. You learn to take deep, calm breaths to ease the body and mind.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 5. Pratyahara (Mastery over the Senses - taste, touch, smell, sight and hearing): This aspect involves turning your attention inward, focusing on yourself and not getting distracted by external elements.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 6. Dharana (Concentration): It means keeping the mind steady and practising single-pointed awareness.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 7. Dhyana (Meditation): Dhyana means deep contemplation or meditation.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 8. Samadhi (State of Bliss): This is a state of profound peace and happiness that comes from practising all the other steps. This is the ultimate goal of Yoga, where you feel completely happy and at peace.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Yoga is a lifelong journey. We have to practice it every day.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Let us start our journey with the first two steps - Yama and Niyama.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: YAMA

subject: XPhy_Education
text: There are five important guidelines for living happily with others according to Ashtanga Yoga; these social disciplines are called Yama. Yama forms the first limb of Ashtanga Yoga. Let’s find out more about these five Yamas.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 1. Ahimsa means being kind and not hurting any living being, including plants and animals.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Satya refers to always telling the truth and being honest. Asteya teaches you to not take things that do not belong to you.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 4. Brahmacharya is about using your energy wisely and having self-control.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 5. Aparigraha means not being greedy and being happy with what you have. (We will explore Aparigraha in detail later in this chapter).

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Let us explore Tapas through an inspiring story.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: TAPAS

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Tapas, one of the five Niyamas, means self-discipline, determination and perseverance.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Imagine you have a big test coming up and instead of waiting until the last minute, you decide to study a little bit each day.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: ss Ae pea and consistent effort is called Tapas.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 120 Khel Yatra

subject: XPhy_Education
text: It’s like training for a sports event, practising an instrument, or helping with chores at home — doing things regularly, even when you don’t feel like it. Tapas teaches that hard work and dedication can help us to achieve our goals and improve ourselves. By practising Tapas, we learn the importance of commitment and how small consistent actions can lead to big results.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Tapas in our life:

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Dedication towards studies, self-discipline, regular exercise for good health, always eating nutritious food, keeping things clean, always speaking the truth, daily practice of Yoga, etc.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: We see many great people around us, their success is inspiring us to set high goals in our lives. Have you heard about the Tapas of these great people? Let us read the inspiring story of Malli Mastan Babu-India’s mountain man to understand the power of Tapas.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Malli Mastan Babu’s Determination

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Malli Mastan Babu was born ina small village in Andhra Pradesh and his father was a farmer. A bright student and eager to learn about new things, Babu studied very hard and went to some of the best schools in India. He got degrees in engineering and management.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: During the course of his studies, Babu developed a keen interest in mountaineering. Inspired by the challenge and beauty of the mountains, he decided to pursue this passion alongside his professional career. He trained hard, learning everything about climbing. He practiced yoga to build physical strength, flexibility and stay mentally focused, all of which helped in his challenging climbs. His dedication to physical fitness, including yoga, was a significant part of his success in achieving numerous expeditions.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: His approach to mountaineering was driven by an unwavering passion and dedication. He believed in pushing his limits and embraced the challenges that came with high-altitude climbing. Through his climbs, he aimed to inspire others to follow their dreams and overcome obstacles, no matter how difficult they might seem.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Babu, whenever on expedition, would plan every last detail. He would start early in the day, carry his own load and walk at a steady clip throughout the day. During his expedition he used to pitch his own tent, cook his own food and fine-tune the next day’s plan with his guide.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Babu’s record-breaking achievement was that he completed climbing seven highest peaks in seven continents in 172 days. With this, Babu set a new benchmark of physical and mental endurance and excellence. He became the first Indian and South Asian to achieve this record, earning him international recognition and admiration.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Even though he is no longer with us, his story is one of extraordinary courage, determination and passion. His life reminds us to dream big, work hard and always do our best. He remains an enduring inspiration to those who dare to push their boundaries and reach for the skies.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: PRATYAHARA

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Pratyahara, the fifth aspect of Ashtanga Yoga, is all about learning to control your senses and focus your mind.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Imagine you are in a noisy room, but you need to concentrate on your homework. Pratyadhara means to restrain or to withdraw, not to get disturbed by things that one sees, hears, smells, tastes or feels.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Pratyahara helps you ignore the noise and focus on what you're doing by tuning out distractions.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: By practising this you learn to turn your attention inward, away from the things around you and become more aware of your thoughts and feelings.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: We sense the world around us through five senses; to focus on the desired activity and avoid distractions, we need to master these senses by practices.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Let’s look at some activities which will help us in turning senses inwards.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 1. Quiet time: Find a comfortable place to sit quietly without any distractions (no TV, mobile phone, or loud noises). Close

subject: XPhy_Education
text: your eyes and focus on your breathing. Fee FS

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Yoga 123

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 2. Mindful eating: Turn off the TV and put away gadgets during meals. Focus on the taste, texture and smell of the food. Chew slowly and enjoy each bite.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 3. Tune with nature: Go for a walkin a parkor garden. Observe the sights, sounds and smells around you without getting lost in thoughts or using electronic devices.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 4. Listening to music: Choose some soothing music, sit quietly and listen to the sounds without doing anything else.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 5. Before going to bed: Spend a few minutes sitting quietly. Close your eyes gently and focus on your breath. Avoid using electronic devices at least 30 minutes before bedtime, instead try to read a book.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: These activities willhelp you to enhance your ability to focus, reduce stress and connect more deeply with yourselves and your surroundings.

text: Chapter 2

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Preparing for Yogic Practices

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Namaste Young Yogis! Are you ready to embark on a journey with the Yogic practices?

subject: XPhy_Education
text: In the previous chapter, you learnt about Yama and Niyama. Here let us explore Asanas, Pranayama, Pratyadhara. Dharana and Dhyana. We will also learn about some other aspects of Yoga, like Krida Yoga in the following chapters, starting with preparatory practices.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Learn these practices under the guidance of your teacher in the school and master them by performing daily at home. Regular practice (sadhana) makes us strong, flexible and calm. It helps us feel peaceful and concentrate better on our homework, during play and in everything we do.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: So, let’s roll out our Yoga mats, take a deep breath and start this amazing adventure together!

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Remember, Yoga is about feeling good; it is important to pay attention to how your body feels during the practice. Never push yourself into a pose that causes pain or discomfort. Before we start Asanas and Prdndydma, it is important to prepare ourselves by doing breathing practices, loosening the joints (Sakshma Vyayama) and flexing the spine (Sithalikarana Vyayama).

subject: XPhy_Education
text: General guidelines to be followed before practising all yogic

subject: XPhy_Education
text: practices.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 1. Do not force yourself to breathe deeply or to hold your breath while doing the Asanas. Breathe normally while doing the Asanas. Always breathe through the nose.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: —_ ML res nas Yoga 12 5

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 2. Always be alert, attentive and watchful when you practice. Concentrate on your pose. Watch your teachers carefully and pay attention to their instructions.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 3. Do not wear shoes or socks while doing the Asanas.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 4. Whenever you are feeling ill or sick, you must rest. If you have a cold, cough, headache, stomach ache, sprained ankle etc., consult your teacher and seek their guidance.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 5. Especially for girls, when you have your menstrual period, inform or consult your teacher before the practice.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Breathing Practices

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Before learning Pranayama, it is necessary to improve the function of the lungs. For healthy lungs, it is necessary to practice proper breathing.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Let us learn about Rabbit and Dog breathing. Rabbit breathing focuses on deep, rhythmic breaths that mimic the breathing pattern of a rabbit. Dog breathing involves mimicking the rapid, shallow breathing of a dog, which can help to release heat from the body and improve breath control.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Breathing practices enhance lung capacity, improve respiratory efficiency, promote relaxation and reduce stress.

text: SUKSHMA VYAYAMA

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Sukshma Vydyama is a series of subtle exercises designed to loosen (release tension) the joints and improve flexibility. The term “Sukshma Vyayama” comes from Sanskrit, where “Sukshma” means “subtle” or “micro” and “Vyadyama” means “exercise” or “movement”. These exercises are gentle, easy to perform and can be practised by people of all ages and fitness levels.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: The exercises involve small, subtle movements that focus on different parts of the body. These movements help to increase circulation, improve joint mobility and release muscular tension. The subtle movements enhance blood flow to various parts of the body, promoting better circulation and oxygenation of tissues.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Each movement is synchronised with the breath, enhancing the flow of Prana (vital energy) throughout the body.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: The simplicity of Sukshma Vyayama makes it accessible to everyone, including the elderly, those with limited mobility or beginners new to Yoga. These exercises can be performed while sitting or standing.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Sukshma Vyayama includes neck exercises, shoulder rotations, finger and wrist movements knee movements, ankle and foot exercises, etc.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Let’s practice Sukshma Vyayama for the neck.

text: SITHALIKARANA VYAYAMA (DYNAMIC PRACTICES)

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Sithalikarana Vyayama refers to a set of loosening exercises that prepare the body for more intense Yoga practices.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Sithalikarana Vyayama is designed to warm up the body, flex the spine by repeatedly stretching and relaxing different muscles. It also improves joint mobility and enhance circulation. These are often used at the beginning of a Yoga session to ensure that the spine and large muscles are adequately prepared for the Asanas.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Sithalikarana Vyayama or dynamic practices:

subject: XPhy_Education

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 2. Bending forward, backward and sideways: Improves mobility and flexibility of the waist region.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 3. Leg swings and rotations: Movements to enhance mobility in the lower body.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 4. Spinal twists: Gentle twists to stretch and relax the spine. In this grade let’s practice Pavanamuktasana Kriya to keep

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Surya Namaskara is a series of 12 powerful Yoga poses performed in a sequence. This practice is traditionally done in the morning to greet the sun and energise the body for the day ahead. Sirya Namaskara combines Asana (postures), Pranayama (breath awareness) and chanting of mantras, making it a comprehensive workout for the body and mind. It serves as an excellent warm-up for more advanced Yoga practices or as a standalone routine for maintaining overall health and well-being.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Asanas

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Asana, the third limb of Ashtanga Yoga, are specialised postures of the body, which help our body to be flexible, strong, balanced and disease-free. Maharsi Patanjali defines Asana as “Sthirm Sukham Asanam” which, meaning to be “able to be in a comfortable position for extended periods.” When Asanas are combined with breath awareness, they cultivate a deeper connection between the body and mind. They also remove physical discomfort and prepare individuals for meditation.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: There are several benefits of practising Asanas every day, some of which are listed below:

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 1. Strength and flexibility:

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Regular practice of Strength

subject: XPhy_Education

subject: XPhy_Education

subject: XPhy_Education

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Flexibility Lightness 2. Improved functioning of

subject: XPhy_Education
text: internal systems: Asanas

subject: XPhy_Education
text: improve blood flow and oxygen delivery to all parts of the body. Many poses stimulate internal organs and glands, thus improving digestion and metabolic functions.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 3. Concentration and relaxation: Practising Asanas helps to calm the mind and reduce stress by focusing on the breath and the body.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 144 Khel Yatra irae tome

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 4. Mind-body connection: Asanas create a harmonious connection between the body and mind, which is essential for spiritual growth and self-awareness.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Are you ready to continue your Yogic journey? Loosen the joints, flex

subject: XPhy_Education
text: the spine and prepare the mind to perform standing, sitting, prone and supine Asanas.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Guidelines for the Practice of Asanas

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 1. Yoga practice should be done in clean and well-ventilated place.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 2. Always use a mat for practice.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 3. Asanas should always be performed empty stomach. Avoid the practice of Asanas for at least four hours after having food. Best is in the morning before going to school.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 4. Spectacles, wrist watches and jewellery should be removed before doing the practice.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 5. Wear loose and comfortable clothes.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Follow the steps given for each Asanas and maintain each posture with closed eyes if possible.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 7. Keep the body relaxed and be aware of your breathing while practising.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 8. Ifyouhave any health problems, inform your teacher before starting Yogic practices.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 9. Relax after performing the Asanas.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 10. Perform all Asanas under the guidance of a teacher.

text: Relaxation — Quick Technique

subject: XPhy_Education
text: After performing Asana, it is advisable to perform relaxation. This helps in releasing any tension in the body and calms down the mind.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Lie on your back with legs apart, hands apart and palms facing the roof. Release the whole body and relax.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Observation of abdominal movements

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Observe the rise and fall of the abdomen as you breathe. Observe for five rounds.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Synchronise breathing with abdominal movements

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Slow down the breathing and synchronise it with abdominal movements.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: While inhaling, the abdomen rises up and while exhaling, take over sinks.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Each inhalation and exhalation together form one round. Observe for five rounds.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Observation of feelings While inhaling, feel the body becoming light and energetic.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: While exhaling, feel the body collapsed and relaxed. Observe for five rounds.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Khel Yatra

subject: XPhy_Education
text: One of the most essential signs of life is breath. It has to function continuously for us to be alive. The quality of breath has a profound impact on the quality of our lives. In Yoga, breath is called manifestation of ‘Prana’ (life force) and ‘Ayama’ is control and expansion of this life force —- breath. There are three important practices in Pranayama.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 1. Inhalation of breath (Puraka)

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 2. Exhalation of breath (Rechaka)

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 3. Retention of breath (Kumbhaka)

subject: XPhy_Education
text: There are several Pranayama techniques (breathing practices) to strengthen the life force. It impacts the smooth functioning of major systems of our body (digestive, circulatory, respiratory, excretory and nervous systems), calm down the mind, improve concentration and helps in achieving overall harmony and well-being.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Pranayama starts with breathing practices to develop healthy habits of deep and rhythmic breathing and being aware of the breath. Pranayama stimulates, calms down and balances the energy channels promoting calmness and clarity.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Techniques like Bhramarit soothe the nervous system and reduce anxiety. There are several other techniques to increase the oxygen supply, energise the body and exercise the lungs. Now, we will learn about:

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 1. Sectional Breathing

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 2. Nadisuddhi Pranayama

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 3. Bhramari Pranayama

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Perform these techniques under the guidance of the teacher and follow the instructions given below.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Guidelines for the practice of Pranayama:

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 1. Breathing in Pranayama should be done through the nose only.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 2. The face, shoulder and other parts of the body should be relaxed while practising Pranayama.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 3. Keep the eyes closed, neck and head straight and spine erect.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 4. Observe the abdominal movement during the Pranayama practice.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 5. Repeat each practice five times to understand it fully and then practice it daily to slowly gain mastery.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Sectional Breathing

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Sectional breathing is a Pranayama technique— that involves consciously directing the breath to specific sections of the lungs to enhance respiratory capacity and awareness. This technique helps practitioners become more aware of their breathing, which improves lung efficiency by fully utilising different parts of the lungs. It also ensures better oxygenation of blood and reduces anxiety through deep mindful breathing.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Let us learn sectional breathing in the following three sections: ¢ Abdominal or diaphragmatic breathing ¢ Thoracic (chest) or intercostal breathing ¢ Clavicular (upper chest) or upper lobar breathing

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Sit in Vajrdsana, Virdsana, Padmasana, or Sukhasana with spine erect, face relaxed and eyes gently closed.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Abdominal or Diaphragmatic Breathing - Adhama Svasa

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 1. Adopt Cin Mudra and keep your hands on your thighs.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 2. Inhale completely so that the abdomen bulges out and the diaphragm is pushed down.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 3. Exhale slowly and completely so that the abdomen is drawn inwards and the diaphragm returns to its normal state.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 4. The inhalation and exhalation should be slow, deep, smooth, relaxed and rhythmic.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 5. There should be no jerks in the whole process. 6. Repeat the practice for five rounds.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Thoracic or (Chest) Intercostal Breathing -— Madhyama Svasa

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 1. Adopt Cinmaya Mudra and keep your hands on your thighs.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 2. Inhale deeply while expanding the chest. 3. Exhale completely while contracting the chest.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: During thoracic breathing, air flows through both the nostrils slowly and continuously and the middle lobes of the lungs open up.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 5. Repeat the practice for five rounds.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Clavicular (Upper Chest) or Upper Lobar Breathing — Adhya Svasa

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 1. Adopt Adi Mudra and keep your hands on your thighs. 2. Inhale deeply while raising the collar bones.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 3. Exhale slowly while bringing back the collar bones to normal position.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 4. Repeat the practice for five rounds.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Physical Education Unit 5.indd 159

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Full Yogic Breathing — Purna Svasa

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 1. Adopt Brahma Mudra as shown in the picture and place it below the navel region

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 2. Inhale deeply while bulging the abdomen, expanding the chest and raising the collar bones.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 3. Exhale slowly while sinking the abdomen, contracting the chest and bringing back the collar bones.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Alternate Nostril Breathing — Nadisuddhi Pranayama or Pranayama

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Nadiguddhi Pranayama is a simple and powerful technique that balances the flow of Prana (life force) and cleans the subtle energy channels. Nadi means energy channels and Suddhi means cleaning. The balanced and rhythmic breathing patterns calm down the mind, reduce anxiety and promote emotional stability.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: A few points are important for the practice of Nadtsuddhi Pranayama:

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 1. Practice this Pranayama daily for long-term benefits. 2. Be aware of the breath while practising.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 3. Let the breath flow naturally.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 4. Avoid jerks or strain during the practice.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Note for the Teacher « Encourage the students to co-ordinate the movement with the breathing. ¢ Ensure students perform sectional breathing smoothly.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Khel Yatra

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Now, let us practice Nadisuddhi Pranayama.

text: Step 1: Sit in Padmasana, Vajrasana, or Sukhasana with the spine erect, face relaxed and eyes gently closed.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Step 2: Adopt Nasika Mudra in the right hand by folding the index and middle finger, placing it on the left thigh. Keep the thumb, the ring finger and the little finger open. Now adopt Cin Mudra in the left hand and place on the left thigh.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Step 3: Close the right nostril with the thumb, and exhale completely through the left nostril. Inhale deeply through the left nostril, hold the breath, lift the thumb from the right nostril and close the left nostril with the ring and the little finger.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Step 4: Exhale slowly through the right nostril. Inhale deeply through the right nostril, lift the ring and little finger from the left nostril and close the right nostril with the thumb.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Step 5: Exhale slowly through the left nostril. This counts as one round. Continue this practice for three to five rounds

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Step 6: After the practice, drop the right hand, adopt Cin Mudra and observe the changes.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Benefits of Nadisuddhi Pranayama

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 1. Nadisuddhi Pranayama promotes balance between both nostrils apart from cleansing the nasal tract.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 2. It increases the appetite. 3. It helps in reducing stress hormones.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Note for the Teacher

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Demonstrate Cin Mudra and Nasika Mudra to the students and ensure they do it properly.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Demonstrate one full cycle of right and left nostril breathing with instructions.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Observe the position of the thumb, ring finger and little finger during the practice to help them understand the technique and follow the steps properly.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: « Ask them how they felt after the practice and if they were able to experience a calm state of mind.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 162 Khel Yatra

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Bhramari Pranayama

subject: XPhy_Education
text: The Bhramart Pranayama technique mimics the humming sound of a female bee. The name “Bhramart” comes from the Sanskrit word “Bhramari,” which means female bee. Bhramari Pranayama is a calming technique, which has a soothing effect on the mind and nervous system. It involves inhaling deeply and producing a low humming sound during exhalation.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Bhramari Pranayama has several benefits: Reduces stress and anxiety. Improves concentration and memory.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 3. Improves sleep quality.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 4. Induces a state of deep relaxation. 5

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Balances blood pressure.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Let us learn how to perform Bhramart Pranayama: e Sit in Sukhasana with the spine erect, face smiling and eyes gently closed.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: ¢ Inhale deeply with both nostrils filling both the lungs.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: e As you exhale, make a steady, low-pitched humming sound like a bee. (Makara sound from Omkara chanting)

subject: XPhy_Education
text: ¢ Feel the vibration of the sound resonate throughout your head and body.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: ¢ Repeat the practice five times.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Note for the Teacher

subject: XPhy_Education
text: ¢ Ask the students whether they could feel the resonance during the practice. Ask about their state of mind after the practice.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Physical Education Unit 5.indd 163

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Pratyahara

subject: XPhy_Education
text: In today’s fast-moving world, Pratyahara assumes a very important role. As all our sense organs are turned outward they respond to speed, it is necessary to learn the art of slowing down or different ways of sublimation or willful withdrawal of our senses.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: The Yogic practice of Pratyahara helps to increase happiness by exercising moderation in food, entertainment, sleep and in all our activities. By practising Pratyahara one can avoid distraction caused by our senses. By doing this one can process the inward journey.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: In the previous chapters, we have learnt various ways of managing the senses through Pratyahara activities.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Chapter 5

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Dharana, Dhyana, and Samadhi

subject: XPhy_Education
text: In this chapter, let us first learn about how to focus before doing Dhyana.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Have you ever sat down calmly with your eyes closed?

subject: XPhy_Education
text: When our eyes are open, we see the world outside and when our eyes are closed, we can experience the world within us.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Dharana, Dhyana and Samadhi are three limbs of Ashtanga Yoga, which deal with focusing and calming the mind to experience peace and joy.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: The first step towards experiencing the peace within is to focus our wandering mind on some object, it can be observing the breath or flame of the candle or the tip of the thumb from the stretched hand. This single-point concentration is called Dharana. Dharana involves keeping the mind steady and maintaining concentration.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Let us learn the art of focusing by practising Jatru Trataka using the shoulders and the thumbs.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Jatru Trataka

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Jatru Trataka is a Yogic gazing that helps to bring one pointed concentration or focus. It is a practice where the gaze is fixed on an object or the target.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: LOT nti

subject: XPhy_Education
text: _ Ag orgs nas Yoga 1 6 5

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Up and Down Viewing

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Step 1: Sit in Vajrdsana or Sukhasana comfortably. Keep your eyes open and hands on the thigh.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Step 2: Lift the right hand to the shoulder level in front, and make a fist with the thumb turned sideward.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Step 3: Focus eyes on the tip of the thumb and slowly start moving the right hand up.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Step 4: Both the eyes must be constantly focused on the tip of the thumb while the hand keeps moving up and down. Do not move the head, but move only the eyeballs up and down. Repeat this practice for three to five rounds.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Step 5: After the practice do simple palming and relax in Vajrdsana or Sukhasana .

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Repeat the same practice on the left side.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 166 Khel Yatra

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Right and Left Viewing

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Physical Education Unit 5.indd 167

subject: XPhy_Education

subject: XPhy_Education

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Sit in Vajrasana or Sukhdasana comfortably. Keep your eyes open and hands on the thighs.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Stretch the right hand in front, and make a fist out of it with the thumb raised upwards.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Move the right hand towards the right shoulder parallel to the ground and keep gazing at the tip of the thumb. Maintain this position for a while by holding the hand at the right end. Slowly move the right hand back to the original position while gazing at the tip of the thumb. Do not move the head but move only the eyeballs sideways.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: After the practice do simple palming and relax in Vajrdsana or Sukhasana.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Simple palming procedure: 1. Rub both palms until they become warm.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 2. Cup your palms and place them gently over the eyes (do not put pressure on the eyeballs).

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 3. Keep the eyes closed.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Keep your palms on your eyes for 10-15 seconds, then gently lift them.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 1. Jatru Trataka improves concentration, intelligence and memory.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 2. It also improves eyesight and vision. 3. It enhances self-confidence, patience and willpower.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: : Limitations: Students with severe headache should avoid the practice.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Note for the Teacher « Ensure that students remove their glasses and wrist watches.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Encourage them to sit with the head, neck and spine erect during the practice. Always open the eyes with a few blinks.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: « Ensure palming is done after each practice.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Khel Yatra

subject: XPhy_Education
text: DHYANA

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Dhyana means meditation, contemplation or reflection of the higher self or God. When concentration becomes uninterrupted and flows continuously like a stream, it transforms into Dhyana. In Dhyana, there is a continuous flow of attention towards the chosen focus without distraction. Unlike Dharana where effort is required to maintain concentration, Dhyana is characterised by a state of effortless presence and immersion in the object of meditation.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Practising Dhyana leads to a profound sense of inner stillness and tranquility. Regular practice of Dhyana enhances mental clarity, sharpens focus, reduces anxiety and improves cognitive function.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Dhyana can be practiced in many ways. In this grade, we will learn about Nadanusandhana (meditating on sound).

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Guidelines for the practice of Dhyana

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 1. Findacalm and clean place. Sit in Padmasana or Sukhasana with the spine erect and the body relaxed.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 2. Select the object of focus, such as a breath or a mantra or some visual object and focus your attention on it. Keep your eyes closed during the practice.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 3. Remain non-reactive to the thoughts or emotions that come up during the practice.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 4. In the beginning it is generally difficult to observe the breath for a long time. If your mind wanders, slowly but firmly bring your attention back to your breath.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 5. Consistency is important; practice dhyana daily, starting with a few minutes and gradually increasing the duration.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Naddanusandhana (Sound meditation)

subject: XPhy_Education
text: The term “Ndda” means sound and “Anusandhdna” means

subject: XPhy_Education
text: investigation or exploration. Therefore, Nddanusandhana

subject: XPhy_Education
text: involves the exploration and deep meditation on sound

subject: XPhy_Education
text: vibrations. Different sounds like A, U, M and AUM are chanted

subject: XPhy_Education
text: slowly so that they generate a fine resonance all over the body.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: ¢ Sit in Vajrasana or Sukhasana with the spine erect, face relaxed and eyes gently closed.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: e Adopt Cin Mudra in both hands and place it on the thighs.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: ¢ Chant Akara for three to five rounds and feel the resonance in the lower body (abdominal).

subject: XPhy_Education
text: e Chant Ukara for three to five rounds and feel the resonance in the middle (chest region) part of the body.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: ¢ Chant Mkara for three to five rounds and feel the resonance in the upper (head region) part of the body.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: ¢ Chant Omkara for three to five rounds and feel the resonance in the body.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: ¢ Repeat the Nadanusandhana several times a day. It helps in the expansion of awareness.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: SAMADHI

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Samadhi is the highest state of consciousness. This is possible to achieve during meditation. In Samadhi, the mind is focused perfectly on the higher self or God for a long time.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Chapter 6

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Krida Yoga

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Various games are designed to understand concepts of Yoga playfully. In Sanskrit, Krida means ‘play’ or ‘sports’; hence, Krida Yoga means learning Yoga through play. Krida Yoga helps in developing some of the principles of Yoga such as joy, being mindful, concentration, strengthening breathing, creativity and love. Krida Yoga helps reduce stress and anxiety, promoting mental well-being and emotional balance.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: By making Yoga enjoyable and interactive, Krida Yoga helps foster a lifelong interest in the practice and supports holistic development.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: A few games are given below, you may design new games based on various principles of Yoga and play with your friends in the class or with members of your family.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Padartha Grahi - Mindful Eating

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Mindful eating is an indoor game, normally played in groups. This game can be used as an “icebreaker”, a game played to reduce inhibitions and to bring out the best in the students. In this game, food is used as a theme to encourage students to develop healthy eating habits. This game brings out creativity, awareness and emotional culture.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: How to play

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 1. Students are instructed to keep their left hand near their chest to resemble a plate.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 172 Khel Yatra irae tome

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 2. The teacher calls out names of different edibles and takes over edible things rapidly.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: For example, Names of vegetables: carrot, pumpkin, paper, beetroot, bat, cabbage, pencil, drumsticks, beans, radish, eraser, potato. Names of fruits: apples, mango, chiku, chair, grapes, orange, desk, banana, grapes, pineapple, duster, papaya, watermelon.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 3. Whenever the teacher names a healthy food item, the students should mime eating from the plate with their right hands and say, “We eat”.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: For example, if the teacher says “Carrot”, the students should do the eating action and say, “We eat”.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 4. The teacher can mix different non-edible items like mud, stone, etc. or junk food in between. For non-edible and junk food items, the students should remain silent.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 5. The students who do the action or say, “We eat”, for non- edible or junk food items are considered out.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 6. Those who remain till the end are declared winners.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Note for the Teacher

subject: XPhy_Education
text: ¢ The teacher can take up the names of healthy food (“We eat”) and junk food (silent). Food items like rice, dosa, dal, chapati, idly, upma, etc., can also be used.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Paficabhita

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Paficabhita is a group game, through which children learn the names of five elements or Paficabhittas as shown in the below picture. This game focuses on awareness, attention, listening comprehension and coordination between the body and the mind. Initially, the teacher has to perform the actions along with the students to understand the instructions of the game.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: How TO PLAY

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 1. The students should stand in a circle with the teacher in the centre.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 2. When the teacher names a paficabhita element students should act as that element as given in the following table.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 3. The speed of these motions can be increased gradually and the order of the Paficabhutas can be mixed.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: 4. The students who do it wrong are out. The student who remains till the end wins the game.

subject: XPhy_Education
text: Note for the Teacher * Variations are encouraged to make the game interesting. ¢ Ensure all students participate in the game.
